explanation: The report is correct. The controlling expression "0 == _MHD_IOV_MAX" is invariant whenever _MHD_IOV_MAX is a compile-time macro (the #ifdef already indicates it is provided at preprocessing time). MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 forbids invariant controlling expressions (the only allowed invariant exceptions are for infinite loops or the do-while false constant case, neither of which applies here). The preceding mhd_assert(0 < _MHD_IOV_MAX) does not remove the fact that the controlling expression is a compile-time constant — an assert is not a language-level change of the expression’s invariance and may be compiled out — so it does not make the runtime controlling expression non-invariant for MISRA purposes. Recommended fixes include: remove the runtime if and handle the zero case via preprocessing (#if _MHD_IOV_MAX == 0 ... or #error), or make the limit come from a non-constant (e.g. an initialized variable) if a runtime check is truly required.
